user.biography:
I’m a bartender located in Portland, Oregon.
I’m also the co-author of The Bar Book and the author of Drinking Distilled.

node.text:
Having just put together a resume for the first time in years, I figured I would share it with those struggling with their own. I also updated my bar resume tutorial for everyone while I was at it. 

The link is in my profile. There, you can download a PDF of my most recent resume, read my resume tutorial, and even download a Google Docs template that you can modify and use as your own. I hope it continues to be of service to other bartenders who need it, especially right now. 

#resumetips #resume #resumewriter #resumehelp #résumé

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on June 29, 2021 tagging @liquor, @domainedecanton, @elijahcraig, @bartenderoftheyear, and @simojoaquin. May be an image of 1 person, child, tree and outdoors.

node.text:
Look at all this love.  It has been a long time, my friends. I got real hooked on being able to see two of my favorite people every year as part of the Heaven Hill Bartender of the Year competition,  and then last year everything was yoinked out from underneath our feet. So this is very, very exciting for me.

In the spirit of recognizing this moment we're all part of, and in lieu of a cocktail competition this year, Bartender of the Year has launched The Craft Meets Community Initiative - a virtual educational and support platform focused on community, advocacy and education. 

Next Tuesday, July 6th, I will finally be rejoined by my friends - two people I have always looked up to, - Lynn House and Joaquin Simo for the #CraftMeetsCommunity seminar that Joaquin and I will be co-presenting. The topic: Education and Mentorship. Something you all know has been incredibly important to me for a long time.

The link to sign up and participate is in my profile, I really hope you'll join us next week. Getting to see all of your faces and sharing what we've learned with you is our favorite part of what we do, so please come spend some time with us!

#BartenderoftheYear #CraftMeetsCommunity #BarEducation #BarMentorship #BarMentor #bartending

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on June 29, 2021 tagging @liquor, @domainedecanton, @elijahcraig, @bartenderoftheyear, and @simojoaquin. May be an image of 1 person, child, tree and outdoors.
Photo shared by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on June 29, 2021 tagging @liquidladylynn. May be an image of 2 people, beard, people standing and indoor.
Tequila Por Mi Amante: fresh strawberries soaked in reposado tequila for three weeks. The color is a bright, beautiful red.

node.text:
Look at that color. Strawberries in reposado tequila for three weeks and then strained, and filtered through a coffee filter for perfect clarity.

Portland is going to be dangerously hot this weekend, so we will be sipping a tiny sample of this rosy elixir next to an undisclosed mountain lake until this brutal heat wave subsides.

#tequila #tequilapormiamante #reposado #strawberries #strawberrymargarita #heatwave #portlandoregon #backpacking #camping #tequila

node.accessibility_caption: Tequila Por Mi Amante: fresh strawberries soaked in reposado tequila for three weeks. The color is a bright, beautiful red.
Heat wave in Portland. 113 degrees on Sunday.
Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in Portland, Oregon. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
I use brown sugar syrups all the time (especially for dark rum Daiquiris this time of year) but I wanted to try to build a sort of “One Brown Sugar  Syrup To Rule Them All”, especially for home use. Rather than having a million different ones in my fridge.

The result is a super flavorful, rich brown sugar syrup that works perfectly in everything from tropical drinks to my beloved Irish Coffee.

As a bonus, it couldn’t be easier to make and is easy to modify to your personal preference. Now I have a brown sugar syrup that is unique to my bar program, which is always a very cool thing to have in one’s back pocket.

Link to the blog post is in my profile. And as they say: Cheers…..enjoy.

#brownsugar #simplesyrup #daiquiri #darkrum #irishcoffee #gingerbeer #bartending #mixology #thebarbook #drinkingdistilled #molasses

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in Portland, Oregon with @lunazultequila. May be an image of strawberry.

node.text:
T E Q U I L A  P O R  M I  A M A N T E

We were driving around yesterday (and of course we have to stop at every roadside farm stand and/or nursery), and Oregon’s own Hood Strawberries are at peak season right now, so I picked up a flat because of COURSE I have to make a big batch of Charles H Baker’s famed Tequila Por Mi Amante every year.

So this morning after my walk I stemmed the entire flat, and then filled this Cambro with a gallon of my favorite delicious @lunazultequila reposado, where it will remain for the next three weeks or so. At which point it will be strained and shared with friends, and stashed away for strawberry margaritas this summer!

More detailed write-up on this easy, delicious, rewarding little yearly project is in the section on infusions in The Bar Book: Elements of Cocktail Technique. #tequila #strawberrymargarita #strawberries #cocktails #tequilapormiamante

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in Heaven Hill Distilleries with @domainedecanton, @liquidladylynn, @elijahcraig, @bartenderoftheyear, and @simojoaquin. May be an image of 12 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
My very favorite thing I do every year outside of work is judge the Heaven Hill Bartender of the Year competition. Yes, it's definitely rewarding to connect with bartenders all over the country, and to learn from them. But really my favorite part is getting to hang out with my friends, especially with Lynn House and Joaquin Simo. Last year we had to do the last city (and the finals, my favorite part) online because you-know-why. But this year we're doing the entire thing a little differently. 2021 is seeing the launch of the Craft Meets Community Initiative. The Craft Meets Community Initiative is a virtual educational and support platform focused on community advocacy and education. The goal is to support, encourage and inspire bartenders who want to make an impact in their bars and the surrounding community. Also included is an optional Award Program where you can submit a project for a chance to win $5,000 and mentoring from an industry expert! And we've got some amazing experts lined up: Claire Spouse, Jackie Summers, Alex Jump, and Lauren Paylor.

The Heaven Hill Bartender of the Year competition has always been about more than making a great cocktail. It’s a search for the bartender who displays all the skills and qualities of a true hospitality professional. Heaven Hill believes that hospitality doesn’t have to stop at the bar door – service can and should extend to the larger community. And that - besides the fact that they make the best products - is why I love getting to work with this company every year. 

I'm gonna throw a link up in my profile. If you're a bartender, please enter! We love getting to meet all of you, it's yet another reason why we keep coming back year after year. #BartenderoftheYear #CraftMeetsCommunity @liquor

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on May 24, 2021 tagging @aussiebarcat. May be an image of snow.

node.text:
As if we needed one more reason to love Uncle Nearest. Not only did they take Best Tennessee Whiskey at the San Francisco World Spirits Competition this year...

But yesterday when I high-centered my truck in some snow that was much, much deeper than it looked, our local Uncle Nearest rep, Jordan Felix, spent the better part of our camping trip underneath it with a shovel getting us loose enough to drive home. 

Now *that’s* a whiskey rep. 😂

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on May 24, 2021 tagging @aussiebarcat. May be an image of snow.
Photo shared by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on May 24, 2021 tagging @sfwspiritscomp, and @unclenearest. May be an image of drink.
Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in Redwood Empire Whiskey with @mcwineweedandwhiskey, and @redwoodempirewhiskey. May be an image of bottle and indoor.

node.text: Thank you, @redwoodempirewhiskey for these delicious samples! What a treat to open this up last night. Rich, full of character from the blended distillates, and complexities from the wood. A lot of wonderful small producers cross my desk regularly but when one stands out it’s even that much better. I can't wait to take a bottle and share it around the campfire this weekend!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in San Francisco, California with @sfwspiritscomp. May be an image of drink and indoor.

node.text:
HUGE congratulations to all of our medal winners at the San Francisco World Spirits Competition this year. You work hard to make a wonderful product, and we're honored to be able to recognize that, and especially to be able to taste all of the spoils of a job well done!

Link to all of our winners is in my profile.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in Portland, Oregon. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'HALF FULL Has the Coronavirus Pandemic Destroyed American Bar Culture? BAR RESCUE As the bar industry continues to be financially decimated, award-winning bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler makes an impassioned plea keep the bar's delicate social fabric intact. Jeffrey Morgenthaler Updated May Published May. 2021 7:23AM ET 2021 4:51AM ET OPINION'.

node.text:
Many, many words have been printed about the economic effects on the bar and restaurant industry over the past fourteen months. I know it’s certainly been at the very front of many of our minds, to say the very least. I don't know anyone who works in this business who isn't kept up at night over it.

But I wanted to share some thoughts on how devastating the past few *years* have been for the delicate social fabric we‘ve woven in bars.  This past year has exacerbated the growing problem of division in this country, and it's yet another mess that the working class has been left to deal with.

My latest essay for The Daily Beast is live now, the link is in my profile. I hope you'll give it a read. And no, that is not a photo of me.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on April 25, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
TWENTY FIVE FUCKING YEARS!!! Holy shit, I can’t believe I started tending bar in 1996. As of today, April 25h, I have been tending bar, full time, for a quarter of a century. (Albeit with a rather spotty schedule over the past year)

This was the first bar I ever worked in. It was the oldest bar in town, and we only served Olympia beer, and bowls of chili. I was the only non-female who worked there, and most of the women I worked with had been there since before I was born. It was a real, legit, old school bar.

I didn't really like it at first, and I wasn't particularly good at it. But at the end of that first summer, I'd learned a lot from my coworkers and I was starting to enjoy it more. I worked there for four years, and then I left to go work in an old VFW hall - a vet's club - because I wanted to learn how to pour liquor. And so I went and learned from another bunch of old-timers. 

I realize that I'm an odd duck for tending bar for this long. But the bartenders I've always looked up to were the ones who stayed behind the bar, and did so because they enjoyed it. I also really enjoy managing bars, and I just don't think I can be a great manager if I'm not doing the same job as the people who are on my team. Kudos to those managers who can run around with a clipboard, but that’s never been my style.

So here's to every one of you out there who's been a bartender for a long-ass time and wants to keep doing it. We need more of you, and I hope you stick it out. I think it’s worth it. 

It’s a little bittersweet today, since I typically celebrate this day by tending bar, but since we're closed for the time being I’m going to get together with another old bartender and raise a glass. Can't wait to get back there and start in on another 25 years very soon. Thanks to every one of you who have been there along the way. #bartender #bartender

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on April 25, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.
Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on April 25, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.
Photo by Jeffrey Morgenthaler on April 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and indoor.

node.text:
The State of Oregon approved restaurant workers for COVID-19 vaccination on April 5th, and after spending many mornings hunched over multiple browser windows on multiple devices trying in vain to book an appointment, I finally got my first shot today! What a stressful process; it was like trying to get concert tickets - you know, back when concerts existed.

Everything else about the experience was incredible once I got to the vaccination site. The place was staffed by people who were there working, by choice, taking care of other human beings. It felt like the very definition of tending bar to me: people taking care of other people and putting up with a whole mess of personalities, both pleasant and unpleasant, while simply doing their best to help.  And also dealing with bodily fluids. So yeah, pretty much exactly like tending bar.

Hospitality has always been about so much more than making fancy cocktails, or answering questions about arcane spirits knowledge. It's about this moment, right here. It's about taking care of your community, it's about helping. It's about taking that core tenet and applying it to all areas of life, not just when you're behind the bar being a rockstar. We aren't just getting vaccinated so that we don't get sick ourselves; we're doing it because we care about others and don't want to get them sick, either.

I know I could have jumped in line well before it was my turn and taken advantage of the very lax eligibility verifications, but I couldn’t bring myself to do it. Half my life has been dedicated to service, and cutting in front of people who the experts deemed deserved it more than I did would have gone against everything I stand for. No shame for my colleagues who felt they needed to go ahead of everyone else, but I'm sure happy that I waited my turn.

If you're a bartender and you're on the fence about getting vaccinated when it's your turn, I implore you to do it.

Second shot is in four weeks. Coming up after that, I'm setting up the bar, turning on the music, turning down the lights, and going back to throwing a fucking party every night for the rest of my life. #bartenderlife #vaccinationdone✔️ #ᴠᴀᴄᴄɪɴᴇssᴀᴠᴇʟɪᴠᴇs #vaccine
